body:
What's going on here: 
```bash
/tmp/pip-install-8a45hy5_/Cython/Cython/Plex/Scanners.c:19:10: fatal error: Python.h: No such file or directory
     #include "Python.h"
              ^~~~~~~~~~
    compilation terminated.
    error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1
```

comment_data.body:
1) Use wheels.
2) Install the Python development package for your system.

@scoder 

>     1. Use wheels.

I am using wheels: 
```bash
# Download the correct Cython 'wheel' from: 
# https://www.lfd.uci.edu/~gohlke/pythonlibs/
# https://pythonwheels.com/

#pip3 install Cython-0.29.13-cp38-cp38-win32.whl
#ERROR: Cython-0.29.13-cp38-cp38-win32.whl is not a supported wheel on this platform.

# BUT this seem to work:
pip install Cython --install-option="--no-cython-compile"
# OK!
```

>     2. Install the Python development package for your system.

I'm pretty sure I have this already, but to make sure, please specify which package exactly? 

---

Then trying to install `lxml`, it errors out with:
```bash

    src/lxml/etree.c:97:10: fatal error: Python.h: No such file or directory
     #include "Python.h"
              ^~~~~~~~~~
    compilation terminated.
    Compile failed: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1
    creating tmp
    cc -I/usr/include/libxml2 -I/usr/include/libxml2 -c /tmp/xmlXPathInit9iebqcyk.c -o tmp/xmlXPathInit9iebqcyk.o
    cc tmp/xmlXPathInit9iebqcyk.o -L/usr/lib -lxml2 -o a.out.exe
    error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1
    ----------------------------------------
ERROR: Command errored out with exit status 1: /usr/bin/python3 -u -c 'import sys, setuptools, tokenize; sys.argv[0] = '"'"'/tmp/pip-install-ma7ttb8p/lxml/setup.py'"'"'; __file__='"'"'/tmp/pip-install-ma7ttb8p/lxml/setup.py'"'"';f=getattr(tokenize, '"'"'open'"'"', open)(__file__);code=f.read().replace('"'"'\r\n'"'"', '"'"'\n'"'"');f.close();exec(compile(code, __file__, '"'"'exec'"'"'))' install --record /tmp/pip-record-p27wiusm/install-record.txt --single-version-externally-managed --compile Check the logs for full command output.

```

Any ideas what's going on here?

Wow, ok, you're using a cutting-edge Python 3.8 on cygwin? That's ambitious. No wonder you're running into obstacles.

I doubt that many projects provide wheels for cygwin. And no, "win32" is not the right wheel architecture for it.

This looks like it could help:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/21843714/cygwin-gcc-issue-cannot-find-python-h
BTW, you should also check if there isn't a ready-made package for Cython and/or lxml in cygwin's package manager already.

@scoder 

> Wow, ok, you're using a cutting-edge Python 3.8 on cygwin? That's ambitious. No wonder you're running into obstacles. I doubt that many projects provide wheels for cygwin. And no, "win32" is not the right wheel architecture for it.

Actually, nowadays it works pretty much flawlessly...until it encounters weird python hacks that try to outsmart the user by looking in various forms of python system info or replacing `\r\n` with `\n` (or vice verse.  Also see the `pyOSinfo` from my [pip-date](https://github.com/E3V3A/pip-date) package, which returns the various platform and os unames etc.

```bash
$ pyOSinfo

Current OS variables as seen by Python3 (3.8.0b4)

os.getenv("TERM"):   xterm
os.name:             posix
os.sys.platform:     cygwin
sys.platform:        cygwin
TRUECOLOR (orange):  TRUECOLOR

os.uname:
        nodename:      xxxx
        machine:       x86_64
        sysname:       CYGWIN_NT-6.3-9600
        release:       3.0.7-338.x86_64
        version:       2019-04-30 18:08 UTC
...
```

---

> This looks like it could help

Yes, interesting. I never had `CC` set to anything and that has worked most of the time. But now I just noticed I have a bunch of compilers in there. To see just a few:

```bash
# ls -1 /usr/bin/*gcc.exe
/usr/bin/gcc.exe*
/usr/bin/i686-w64-mingw32-gcc.exe*
/usr/bin/x86_64-pc-cygwin-gcc.exe*
/usr/bin/x86_64-w64-mingw32-gcc.exe*
```

so perhaps `export CC=/usr/bin/x86_64-w64-mingw32-gcc.exe` might just work.
I will definitely try this next time, because I just resolved the issue by compiling from 
fresh sources using:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/lxml/lxml.git lxml
cd lxml
python3.8 setup.py install
```

:+1:

title: compile error Python.h not found
